clarifying_information.clarifying_question1: Are you interested in strategies that enhance LNP accumulation in the liver for improved hepatocyte targeting, or methods to reduce and redirect LNP accumulation away from the liver?

clarifying_answer1.clarifying_answer: I am interested in strategies that enhance LNP accumulation in the liver for improved hepatocyte targeting.

clarifying_information.clarifying_question2: Do you want to focus on specific experimental approaches such as modifying LNP size and charge, PEGylation, surface ligand conjugation, or pre-treatment RES-blockade strategies to control liver accumulation?

clarifying_answer2.clarifying_answer: Yes, I would like to focus on specific experimental approaches such as modifying LNP size and charge, PEGylation, surface ligand conjugation, and pre-treatment RES-blockade strategies to control liver accumulation.

clarifying_information.clarifying_question3: Are you looking for strategies to target specific liver cell types (e.g., hepatocytes, Kupffer cells, LSECs) with LNPs, or for approaches that minimize non-specific liver uptake to improve extrahepatic delivery?

clarifying_answer3.clarifying_answer: I am interested in strategies to target specific liver cell types (e.g., hepatocytes, Kupffer cells, LSECs) with LNPs, rather than minimizing non-specific liver uptake for extrahepatic delivery.

better_query: What experimental strategies can be employed to enhance LNP accumulation in the liver, specifically for improved targeting of hepatocytes, and how do approaches such as modifying LNP size, charge, and PEGylation contribute to this?

sections.title: Introduction to LNPs and liver targeting
sections.tldr: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) naturally accumulate in the liver due to its unique blood filtering function and fenestrated endothelium. This natural tropism makes LNPs ideal delivery vehicles for hepatocyte-targeted therapeutics, though their efficiency requires optimization. (LLM Memory)
sections.text: Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) are advanced drug delivery systems composed of ionizable lipids, helper lipids, cholesterol, and PEG-lipids that have emerged as the leading platform for RNA therapeutics. The liver represents a primary target for LNP-based therapies due to its natural role in filtering blood and metabolizing foreign substances. When administered intravenously, LNPs exhibit inherent hepatic tropism, with approximately 60-80% of the injected dose accumulating in the liver. This natural targeting occurs primarily because the liver's unique vascular structure features fenestrated endothelium with pores (100-150 nm in diameter) that allow LNPs to extravasate from bloodstream into the space of Disse, where they can interact with hepatocytes. Additionally, the liver's resident macrophages (Kupffer cells) actively capture circulating nanoparticles, contributing to hepatic accumulation. While this natural tropism is advantageous for liver-directed therapies, optimizing LNP formulations specifically for hepatocyte targeting remains crucial, as non-specific uptake by Kupffer cells and other non-parenchymal cells can reduce therapeutic efficacy. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Size optimization for hepatocyte targeting
sections.tldr: LNP size critically affects liver cell targeting with particles around 60-80 nm showing optimal hepatocyte delivery by passing through liver fenestrations (100-150 nm) while avoiding clearance by Kupffer cells. Larger particles (>100-200 nm) cannot access hepatocytes effectively but can be leveraged for targeting liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs). (10 sources)
sections.text:
The size of lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) plays a decisive role in determining their cellular distribution within the liver and significantly impacts therapeutic efficacy. Liver architecture features fenestrated endothelium with pores measuring approximately 100-150 nm in diameter in humans and 140 nm in mice, creating a physical barrier that limits particle access to hepatocytes based on size. <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232059366" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> A clear hierarchy in gene silencing potency has been observed with LNP-siRNA systems, where particles around 80 nm demonstrate maximum hepatocyte targeting efficiency (78 nm > 42 nm > 38 nm >> 27 nm > 117 nm). <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> This optimal size range results from a balance between two factors: smaller particles (<30 nm) have reduced stability and fusogenicity, while larger particles (>100 nm) cannot effectively penetrate through hepatic fenestrations to reach hepatocytes. <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

More recent studies suggest that even smaller LNPs (50-60 nm) may offer superior performance in non-human primates, showing approximately 5-fold higher protein expression in liver compared to conventional larger particles (70-80 nm). <Paper corpusId="276413641" paperTitle="(Hosseini-Kharat et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> This size-dependent efficacy is particularly evident when LNPs are administered intravenously, as particles must navigate through the liver's sinusoidal architecture to reach their target cells. <Paper corpusId="259236911" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> Studies have also demonstrated that 60 nm LNPs show tropism for hepatocytes, making them particularly suited for hepatocyte-specific targeting applications. <Paper corpusId="261091800" paperTitle="(2023)" isShortName></Paper>

Interestingly, the relationship between size and liver accumulation creates opportunities for targeting different cell populations within the liver. While smaller LNPs (60-80 nm) preferentially target hepatocytes, particles with sizes between 100-200 nm are more suitable for liver sinusoidal endothelial cell (LSEC) targeting. <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261091800" paperTitle="(2023)" isShortName></Paper> This differential targeting based on size can be leveraged for cell-specific therapeutic approaches within the liver microenvironment. <Paper corpusId="232059366" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

The impact of size on LNP biodistribution extends beyond the liver. Larger LNPs exhibit reduced liver uptake following intravenous, intramuscular, and subcutaneous administration. <Paper corpusId="250972048" paperTitle="(Kularatne et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="266385029" paperTitle="(Chan et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> This property can be exploited to redirect LNPs to other organs or to enhance targeted delivery within the liver. For instance, Saunders et al. developed "nanoprimers" - non-toxic liposomes larger than liver fenestrae - that transiently occupy reticuloendothelial system (RES) cells in the liver prior to LNP administration, improving therapeutic nucleic acid delivery to hepatocytes. <Paper corpusId="250244349" paperTitle="(Albertsen et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="218480033" paperTitle="(Saunders et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>

Size optimization must be considered alongside other LNP properties such as surface charge, PEGylation, and targeting ligands to achieve optimal hepatocyte targeting. <Paper corpusId="232059366" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> The intricate relationship between these factors requires careful formulation design to maximize therapeutic efficacy while minimizing off-target effects. <Paper corpusId="263840863" paperTitle="(Youssef et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Lipid nanoparticle technology for therapeutic gene regulation in the liver

snippets: A number of recent studies have demonstrated that LNP systems accumulate in various cell types within the liver (Shi et al., 2011)(Sago et al., 2019)(Paunovska et al., 2019)(Sato et al., 2016). Important physicochemical characteristics that modulate intrahepatic LNP distribution and activity are particle size, apparent pKa value (and resulting surface charge), and lipase sensitivity (Sato et al., 2016)

A recent study by Chen et al. investigated how LNP size (30 nm -120 nm) influences gene silencing in hepatocytes (Chen et al., 2016). A clear hierarchy in gene silencing potency was observed with LNP-siRNA systems around 80 nm exhibiting maximum activity (78 nm > 42 nm > 38 nm >> 27 nm > 117 nm). This LNP size optimum results from a combination of two factors: 1) smaller particles being less active (less stable and less fusogenic); and 2) larger particles (>100 nm), not being able to access hepatocytes (limited by fenestrations)
LNP sizes between 120 nm to 200 nm could be used for LSEC targeting

A key advance during the development of Onpattro® for hepatocyte gene silencing was identifying an optimized ionizable cationic lipid with an apparent pKa between 6.2 and 6.5 (Cullis et al., 2017)(Jayaraman et al., 2012). Further increasing the pKa value to 7.15 resulted in improved gene silencing in LSECs (Sato et al., 2016)(Shobaki et al., 2018). Incorporating ionizable cationic lipids exhibiting higher pKa values increased accumulation in the MPS, most likely due to scavenger receptor recognition [159].

paper.title: Engineered ionizable lipid nanoparticles for targeted delivery of RNA therapeutics into different types of cells in the liver

snippets: Given their physiological differences, a cell type-specific delivery of RNA in the liver requires a precise engineering of LNPs

For example, LSECs have the highest endocytic capacity without a basement membrane, making them the most permeable among liver cells (Braet et al., 2002). LSECs have many fenestrae, allowing the facile transport of macromolecules between sinusoidal lumen and hepatocytes. Because of the average diameter of liver fenestrae (~100 nm in human and ~140 nm in mouse), only small nanoparticles can penetrate through these holes (Wisse et al., 2008). Chen and coworkers (Chen et al., 2016) previously reported the effect of particle size on the in vivo potency of LNPs in the liver. They showed that the particle size heavily influenced the gene delivery efficacy of LNPs, as well as the stability of LNPs during blood circulation
By introducing unique targeting ligands to the highly PEGylated LNPs, ApoE-mediated cellular uptake can be blocked and selective delivery of LNPs can be achieved

our results successfully demonstrated the targeted delivery of RNA into different types of cells in the liver by controlling physical size of LNPs, PEG-lipid content, and incorporation of active targeting ligands.

paper.title: Why do lipid nanoparticles target the liver? Understanding of biodistribution and liver-specific tropism

snippets: LNPs are effective in targeting the liver; however, to understand their localization, it is important to distinguish biodistribution from functional delivery. This distinction helps clarify how LNPs can target specific organs such as the liver while guaranteeing the therapeutic cargo is effectively delivered in the target cells. (Sago et al., 2019)(Khalil et al., 2020) Biodistribution is the process of LNPs accumulating in specific tissues after entering circulation, while functional delivery depends on the successful release and action of the therapeutic cargo (e.g., mRNA or small interfering RNA [siRNA]) in target cells. (Kong et al., 2024) This distinction is important because LNPs can accumulate in tissues such as the liver without producing intended therapeutic effects

Functional delivery is also impacted by challenges in intracellular trafficking and cargo release once inside cells. [58] Several studies have demonstrated rapid liver accumulation of LNPs within minutes of administration, largely due to the liver's extensive blood flow and porous endothelium. 24,35,59 However, this high level of accumulation does not directly translate to efficient functional delivery. Recent work by Lam et al. 60 showed that while LNPs of different sizes can accumulate similarly in the liver, their functional delivery to hepatocytes varies between species. In non-human primates, smaller LNPs (50-60 nm) showed approximately 5-fold higher protein expression in liver compared with conventional larger particles (70-80 nm)

Surface chemistry was important for targeting efficiency. PEG lipids improved circulation, while sheddable variants (e.g., pH-sensitive or enzymatically cleavable PEG) helped target the liver. Mannose-PEG, on the other hand, enhanced receptor-specific delivery to LSECs. (Kim et al., 2021) pH-sensitive PEGylated lipids increased the stability of the formulation and enabled efficient liver genome editing. (Chen et al., 2024) Siloxane-incorporated lipidoids also improved endosomal escape and liver-specific mRNA delivery. 72

Kupffer cells often sequester LNPs, reducing delivery to hepatocytes. However, depletion strategies have been shown to improve hepatocyte targeting by minimizing LNP clearance by Kupffer cells. (Tavares et al., 2017) For example, depletion of Kupffer cells was shown to improve nanoparticle delivery to tumors by up to 150-fold, though the maximum tumor accumulation remains only 2% of the injected dose, demonstrating systemic challenges in nanoparticle targeting. LSECs, because of their fenestrations, facilitated selective delivery, such as for receptor-specific LNPs. (Kim et al., 2021)

paper.title: Immune-Modulating Lipid Nanomaterials for the Delivery of Biopharmaceuticals

snippets: Most of the currently studied LNPs show affinity for the liver because it is a well-perfused organ that can take up intravenously injected cargo, and the slow blood flow and sinusoidal vasculature of the liver also play a role in aiding LNP distribution (Sago et al., 2018)(Katakowski et al., 2015). In addition, neutrally charged LNPs that enter the bloodstream bind to apolipoprotein E (ApoE), which is taken up through low-density lipoprotein receptors distributed in the liver [41]. Thus, neutral LNPs can rapidly accumulate in the liver without using ligands for molecules overexpressed by hepatocytes. Even if the LNP surface is PEGylated, it has been reported that PEGylated lipids and ApoE proteins are exchanged after injection into the bloodstream (Patel et al., 2020)

Attempts have been made to modulate the surface charge of LNPs in order to deliver drugs to organs other than the liver. Lung-specific mRNA delivery has been achieved by increasing the proportion of persistent cationic lipids in LNPs; conversely, spleen-specific mRNA distribution has been observed when the surface negative charge is high (Huang et al., 2022)

The method of reducing the diameter of the nanoparticles for tumor penetration has also been studied. Using a microfluidic mixing technique, siRNA-LNPs with sizes of less than 50 nm were prepared and efficiently invaded the tumor microenvironment (Sato et al., 2016). In another study, improved penetration into diseased tissues, such as tumors, was observed using LNPs with a diameter of 30 nm (Chen et al., 2016). Recently, it was shown that LNPs as small as 20 nm in diameter can be produced by increasing the PEGylation ratio using microfluidic technology.

paper.title: Targeting materials and strategies for RNA delivery

snippets: Additionally, researchers discovered that altering the size, adjusting PEG-lipid content, or incorporating ligands in LNPs affected the distribution of loaded cargoes in hepatocytes and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs), or increased the delivery efficiency in extrahepatic organ. For instance, LNPs with 100 nm diameter in size are the most effective for targeting LSECs, while LNPs with smaller diameters, such as 60 nm, showed tropism for hepatocytes [67].

paper.title: The Future of Tissue-Targeted Lipid Nanoparticle-Mediated Nucleic Acid Delivery

snippets: The liver is the primary organ of LNP accumulation following intravenous administration and is also observed to varying degrees following intramuscular and subcutaneous routes, with larger LNP having less liver uptake (Di et al., 2022)

Akinc et al. discovered that adsorption of endogenous apolipoprotein E (ApoE) can direct the uptake of LNP to hepatocytes through interaction with the low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR) located in these cells (Akinc et al., 2010). These researchers characterized this uptake mechanism by using LDLR knockout mice and hepatocytes in vitro and went on to show that the N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) ligand covalently attached to LNP could also target hepatocytes through the asialoglycoprotein receptor (Table 1). The utility of GalNAc-mediated hepatocyte targeting of LNP is demonstrated by the recent approval of Onpattro transthyretin siRNA for hereditary amyloidosis mentioned above

The LNP surface charge has been shown to influence the liver accumulation of intramuscularly administered LNP, with negatively charged LNP having greater liver uptake (Carrasco et al., 2021). Similarly, the inclusion of neutral lipids to LNP resulted in liver tropism following intravenous injection, while the addition of cationic lipids to net neutral LNP resulted in a shift to lung uptake and the addition of negatively charged lipids to net neutral LNP resulted in splenic uptake (Cheng et al., 2020). The addition of oxidized cholesterol to LNP shifted liver uptake away from hepatocytes and into the hepatic microenvironment, including Kupffer cells and hepatic endothelial cells (Paunovska et al., 2019). The inclusion of constrained lipids in LNP, such as adamantyl phospholipids, has also been shown to target hepatic Kupffer cells (Gan et al., 2020). Apart from charge and composition, size can also influence hepatocyte transfection, presumably due to the hepatic architecture, with narrow sinusoidal fenestration pores of ~100 nm (Desjardins et al., 2003); LNP > ~200 nm dramatically diminishes hepatocyte transfection (Basha et al., 2011).

paper.title: Intracellular Protein Delivery: Approaches, Challenges, and Clinical Applications

snippets: Multiple reports have also demonstrated that both charge and size of LNPs affect their tropism and delivery to different immune cell subtypes [274]. For example, preferential organ accumulation of systemically administered ionizable LNPs can be modulated by the amount of cationic lipids used during formulation [172,173]. Moreover, differential delivery of RNA LNPs to cell types within the liver is also possible by adjusting the proportion of PEG-lipid [273]. Notably, liver accumulation is known to correlate positively with particle size. This trend holds true for many classes of nanoparticles including AuNPs [270], SiNPs [271], and polymeric nanoparticles [272] Conversely, smaller nanoparticles (<5 nm) are typically excreted in the urine. In nearly all cases, coating nanoparticles with polyethylene glycol (PEG) confers "stealth" properties for prolonged circulation and evasion of excretion.

paper.title: The role of lipid components in lipid nanoparticles for vaccines and gene therapy

snippets: Studies including (Chen et al., 2016) have shown that preference for hepatocytes over the reticuloendothelial system (RES), which includes Kupffer cells and LSECs, can be tuned by making LNP sizes either smaller or larger than the diameter of the fenestrations in the liver (50-300 nm (Horn et al., 1987) and 107 ± 1.5 nm (Lokugamage et al., 2021))

Saunders et al. (Saunders et al., 2020) administered non-toxic liposomes, termed nanoprimers, that were larger than the fenestrae of the liver capillaries and designed to transiently occupy RES cells in the liver prior to LNP administration. This strategy improved LNP nucleic acid-mediated knockdown and translation efficiency of targets in hepatocytes.

paper.title: A Nanoprimer to improve the systemic delivery of siRNA and mRNA.

snippets: Despite tremendous interest in gene therapies, the systemic delivery of nucleic acids still faces substantial challenges. To successfully administer nucleic acids, one approach is to encapsulate them in lipid nanoparticles (LNPs). However, LNPs administered intravenously substantially accumulate in the liver where they are taken up by the reticuloendothelial system (RES). Here, we administer prior to the LNPs a liposome designed to transiently occupy liver cells, the Nanoprimer. This study demonstrates that the pretreatment of mice with the Nanoprimer decreases the LNPs' uptake by the RES. By accumulating rapidly in the liver cells, the Nanoprimer improves the bioavailability of the LNPs encapsulating human erythropoietin (hEPO) mRNA or factor VII (FVII) siRNA, leading respectively to more hEPO production (by 32%) or FVII silencing (by 49%). The use of the Nanoprimer offers a new strategy to improve the systemic delivery of RNA-based therapeutics.

paper.title: Enabling mRNA Therapeutics: Current Landscape and Challenges in Manufacturing

snippets: Studies evaluating lipid-based systems administered through subcutaneous and intramuscular injection have shown clear effects of the size on their uptake (Hassett et al., 2021)(Oussoren et al., 1997)
As previously established, administration of LNPs through intravenous and intramuscular methods leads to non-specific accumulation of the particles in the liver (Pardi et al., 2015)
The ability to redirect mRNA LNP therapeutics to their target tissue is therefore critical in order to reduce off-target effects (Dirisala et al., 2023)

selective organ targeting (SORT) nanoparticles, developed by Cheng et al., demonstrated that supplementing currently established LNP compositions with specified percentages of charged molecules can alter tissue tropism (Cheng et al., 2020)
Coating strategies for mRNA LNPs have also been explored [210], including new avenues being PEG coatings for redirection of other nanoparticles from the liver to the target tissue [211]212].

sections.title: Surface charge and ionizable lipid optimization
sections.tldr: The surface charge and ionizable lipid properties of LNPs critically influence their liver targeting ability and cellular distribution within the liver. Optimal pKa values (6.2-6.5) enhance hepatocyte delivery, while higher pKa values (>7.0) redirect LNPs to liver sinusoidal endothelial cells, offering precise control over intrahepatic targeting. (16 sources)
sections.text:
The surface charge characteristics of lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) play a fundamental role in determining their liver accumulation and distribution among different hepatic cell populations. LNPs containing ionizable lipids with an optimal apparent pKa between 6.2 and 6.5 demonstrate superior hepatocyte-specific gene silencing efficiency, as discovered during the development of Onpattro® <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="40205755" paperTitle="(Jayaraman et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. This narrow pKa range allows LNPs to maintain a near-neutral charge in circulation (pH ~7.4) while becoming positively charged in the acidic endosomal environment, facilitating endosomal escape and cytosolic delivery.

Intriguingly, modifying the pKa value provides precise control over the intrahepatic distribution of LNPs. Increasing the pKa value to approximately 7.15 shifts LNP targeting from hepatocytes to liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="205208610" paperTitle="(Sato et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="56895022" paperTitle="(Shobaki et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This ion-based physical targeting approach leverages complementary charges between LNPs and target tissues to enhance selective uptake <Paper corpusId="56895022" paperTitle="(Shobaki et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Further increasing the pKa beyond 7.15 promotes accumulation in the mononuclear phagocyte system (MPS), likely due to recognition by scavenger receptors <Paper corpusId="220281961" paperTitle="(Witzigmann et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The relationship between surface charge and organ tropism extends beyond intrahepatic targeting. The incorporation of neutral lipids in LNPs maintains their natural liver tropism following intravenous injection, while adding cationic lipids shifts biodistribution toward the lungs, and incorporating negatively charged lipids redirects LNPs to the spleen <Paper corpusId="250972048" paperTitle="(Kularatne et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="214808084" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach, termed selective organ targeting (SORT), allows for tissue-specific delivery by manipulating LNP surface charge through the addition of supplemental targeting molecules <Paper corpusId="263840863" paperTitle="(Youssef et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="214808084" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The mechanism behind charge-mediated tissue targeting involves protein adsorption onto the LNP surface. Neutrally charged LNPs bind to apolipoprotein E (ApoE), which facilitates hepatocyte uptake through low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDLR) <Paper corpusId="259236911" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="47397011" paperTitle="(Akinc et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Different surface charges attract distinct serum proteins, creating unique protein coronas that influence biodistribution <Paper corpusId="245405261" paperTitle="(Dilliard et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, introducing positive charge through cationic lipids shifts the protein corona from apolipoprotein-rich to vitronectin-rich, affecting targeting efficiency <Paper corpusId="269120128" paperTitle="(Huang et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The route of administration also affects how surface charge influences LNP distribution. For intramuscularly administered LNPs, negatively charged particles demonstrate greater liver uptake <Paper corpusId="250972048" paperTitle="(Kularatne et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="236989455" paperTitle="(Carrasco et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This suggests that controlling surface charge is critical for minimizing off-target systemic expression following local administration of mRNA-LNP vaccines <Paper corpusId="236989455" paperTitle="(Carrasco et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Additionally, specialized lipid modifications can further refine hepatic cell targeting. The incorporation of oxidized cholesterol shifts liver uptake from hepatocytes to Kupffer cells and hepatic endothelial cells <Paper corpusId="250972048" paperTitle="(Kularatne et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="73435998" paperTitle="(Paunovska et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>, while adamantyl phospholipids enhance targeting to Kupffer cells <Paper corpusId="250972048" paperTitle="(Kularatne et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="218998732" paperTitle="(Gan et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Recent studies also suggest that removing cholesterol from LNP formulations can reduce liver accumulation and increase delivery to the spleen <Paper corpusId="277818634" paperTitle="(Hu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="270982455" paperTitle="(Su et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Maximizing the Potency of siRNA Lipid Nanoparticles for Hepatic Gene Silencing In Vivo**

snippets: Special (lipid) delivery: The role of the ionizable lipid pK(a) in the in vivo delivery of siRNA by lipid nanoparticles has been studied with a large number of head group modifications to the lipids. A tight correlation between the lipid pK(a) value and silencing of the mouse FVII gene (FVII ED(50) ) was found, with an optimal pK(a) range of 6.2-6.5. The most potent cationic lipid from this study has ED(50) levels around 0.005 mg kg(-1) in mice and less than 0.03 mg kg(-1) in non-human primates.

paper.title: Relationship Between the Physicochemical Properties of Lipid Nanoparticles and the Quality of siRNA Delivery to Liver Cells.

snippets: While a variety of short interfering RNA (siRNA) delivery compounds have been developed, a deep understanding of the key parameters that determine the quality of siRNA delivery are not known with certainty. Therefore, an understanding of the factors required for the efficient, selective, and safe delivery of siRNA is a great challenge for successful siRNA delivery. Herein, we report on the development of two pH-sensitive cationic lipids and their use in examining the impact of the acid dissociation constant (pKa) value, lipase sensitivity and the size of lipid nanoparticles on the biodistribution, and efficiency and cell specificity of gene silencing in the liver. An increase in the pKa value resulted in a significant change in the intrahepatic localization of siRNA and gene-silencing efficiency in hepatocytes and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs). The sensitivity of the pH-sensitive cationic lipid to lipases was a major factor in achieving hepatocyte-specific gene silencing. Increasing the particle size can improve the LSEC specificity of gene silencing. As a consequence, we succeeded in developing both a highly efficient, hepatocyte-specific formulation, and the most efficacious LSEC-targeted formulation reported to date. These findings will facilitate the development of more sophisticated siRNA delivery systems.

paper.title: Mixing lipids to manipulate the ionization status of lipid nanoparticles for specific tissue targeting

snippets: The aim of this study was to improve the targeting efficiency of an LNP by optimizing the dissociation constant (pKa) value for its membrane, which reflects its ionization property or surface charge. This would permit electrostatic interactions with targeted tissues since both structures would have complementary charges. This could selectively enhance the uptake of LNPs by tissues of interest with minimal distribution to others, in a process that is called ionic-based physical targeting

We also found that the pKa value of the LNP membrane influences its intrahepatic distribution. For example, LNPs that contain lipids with low pKa values (eg, YSK05 and YSK13-C3 with pKa values of 6.50 and 6.45 pKa, respectively) are distributed in hepatocytes. Whereas, those containing lipids with higher pKa values (eg, YSK13-C4 and YSK15-C4 with pKa values of 6.80 and 7.10, respectively) are distributed in LSECs, (Sato et al., 2016) which are border cells that are located between hepatocytes and the blood stream. (Wisse, 1970)(Wisse, 1972)
